* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is not a valid [polymorphable](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") form.

* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").

| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          | [SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line3569](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line3569 "SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c")                                                                                                                                                                                                           |

**Frankenstein's Monster**, ', is a [unique](/wiki/Unique "Unique") [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") and [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"). He is a [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong"), [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem") that is very similar to a more powerful [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem").

Frankenstein's Monster has two claw attacks and possesses [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [shock resistance](/wiki/Shock_resistance "Shock resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

Eating the [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of Frankenstein's Monster grants one of cold resistance, shock resistance, sleep resistance, or poison resistance, with an equal 1⁄4 chance (25%) of each.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [5 References](#References)

## Generation

Frankenstein's Monster is always created hostile, and will always generate with 400 [HP](/wiki/HP "HP").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) He is not a valid form for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

Frankenstein's Monster is guaranteed to appear in [Frankenstein's Lab](/wiki/Frankenstein%27s_Lab "Frankenstein's Lab"), where he is found wandering the maze surrounding the lab at level creation.

Frankenstein's Monster leaves a corpse that is aged 100 turns upon death.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Strategy

While Frankenstein's Monster has a lot of HP, solid [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of -5 and a sizable [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 50, he is slow at 8 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed") and unlikely to be a threat for any [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") that has reached [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") and found the laboratory's branch: his melee attacks hit only moderately hard for the depth he is encountered at, he lacks special abilities, and he is fairly slow at 8 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"). Most players can take advantage of his vulnerability to [fire](/wiki/Fire "Fire") damage to make the fight much quicker.

As Frankenstein's Monster is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless"), locating him can be difficult - [quaffing](/wiki/Quaffing "Quaffing") a blessed [potion of monster detection](/wiki/Potion_of_monster_detection "Potion of monster detection") or casting the [detect monsters](/wiki/Spellbook_of_detect_monsters "Spellbook of detect monsters") spell with Skilled or higher [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill") level in [divination spells](/wiki/Divination_spells "Divination spells") can make him easy to spot. For heroes who are determined to kill him, the corpse is generally unsuitable for consumption without using a [tinning kit](/wiki/Tinning_kit "Tinning kit"), but can provide valuable resistances should they lack any.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Frankenstein's monster](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankenstein%27s_monster "wikipedia:Frankenstein's monster")***

Frankenstein's monster (or Frankenstein's Creature) is the main antagonist of 1818 [Mary Shelley](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Shelley "wikipedia:Mary Shelley") novel *[Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankenstein "wikipedia:Frankenstein")*. The story itself begins with Captain Robert Walton on an exploration of the North Pole: Walton had come to the area in pursuit of scientific knowledge, and during the voyage his crew spotted a dog sled driven by a gigantic figure, later revealed to be Frankenstein's monster. A few hours later, they rescue a freezing and emaciated man from near-death, who identifies himself as [Victor Frankenstein](/wiki/Doctor_Frankenstein "Doctor Frankenstein"), the monster's creator; Victor then recounts his life story to Captain Walton as a warning.

While at university, Victor Frankenstein excels in chemistry and other sciences, developing a secret technique to give life to non-living matter. He undertakes the creation of a humanoid being over the course of two years in the attic of his boarding house in Ingolstadt. Due to the difficulty of replicating the minute parts of the human body, Victor makes his monster about 8 feet (2.4 m) in height and proportionally large, and selects for features commonly considered beautiful during the process.

Despite this, when the monster is finally animated he takes on a hideous appearance, with dull and watery yellow eyes and yellow skin that barely conceals the muscles and blood vessels underneath. Repulsed by his work, Victor flees from it in horror; frightened, and unaware of his own identity, the monster wanders through the wilderness. Far from being an unintelligent brute, the monster is an emotional, contemplative being that attempts to fit into human society, but his shunning leads him to seek revenge against Frankenstein.

Frankenstein's monster has since become iconic in popular culture, and has been featured in various forms of media, including films, television series, merchandise and video games; due to his significant role, the monster is commonly and erroneously referred to by "Frankenstein", his creator's name. The most popularly recognized versions are the trilogy of film portrayals by [Boris Karloff](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Karloff "wikipedia:Boris Karloff"): the 1931 film *[Frankenstein](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankenstein_\(1931_film\) "wikipedia:Frankenstein (1931 film)")*, the 1935 sequel *[Bride of Frankenstein](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bride_of_Frankenstein "wikipedia:Bride of Frankenstein")*, and the 1939 sequel *[Son of Frankenstein](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Son_of_Frankenstein "wikipedia:Son of Frankenstein")*. Frankenstein's monster is described by scholar [Joseph Carroll](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Carroll_\(scholar\) "wikipedia:Joseph Carroll (scholar)") as occupying "a border territory between the characteristics that typically define protagonists and antagonists".

## Encyclopedia entry

With an anxiety that almost amounted to agony, I collected  
the instruments of life around me, that I might infuse a spark  
of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet. It was  
already one in the morning; the rain pattered dismally against  
the panes, and my candle was nearly burnt out, when, by the  
glimmer of the half-extinguished light, I saw the dull yellow  
eye of the creature open; it breathed hard, and a convulsive  
motion agitated its limbs.  
  
How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, or how  
delineate the wretch whom with such infinite pains and care I  
had endeavoured to form? His limbs were in proportion, and I  
had selected his features as beautiful. Beautiful!--Great God!  
His yellow skin scarcely covered the work of muscles and  
arteries beneath; his hair was of a lustrous black, and  
flowing; his teeth of a pearly whiteness; but these luxuriances  
only formed a more horrid contrast with his watery eyes, that  
seemed almost of the same colour as the dun white sockets in  
which they were set, his shrivelled complexion and straight  
black lips.

\[ Frankenstein, by Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [makemon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 2261](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/makemon.c#line2261 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/makemon.c")
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [mon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 258](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mon.c#line258 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mon.c")

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
Frankenstein's Monster

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
' Frankenstein's Monster
Difficulty 23
Attacks Claw 3d8 physical, Claw 3d8 physical
' Frankenstein's Monster
Difficulty 23
Attacks

Claw 3d8 physical, Claw 3d8 physical

Base level 20
Base experience 635
Speed 8
Base AC -5
Base MR 50
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) Unique
Genocidable no
Weight 1400
Nutritional value 600
Size large
Resistances cold resistance, shock resistance, sleep resistance, poison resistance, drain resistance
Resistances conveyed cold (25%), shock (25%), sleep (25%), poison (25%)

Frankestein's Monster:

  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is undead.
  • is male.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • is strong.
Reference SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line3569

Frankenstein's Monster, ', is a unique monster that appears in SLASH'EM and SlashTHEM. He is a strong, undead golem that is very similar to a more powerful flesh golem.

Frankenstein's Monster has two claw attacks and possesses cold resistance, shock resistance, sleep resistance, and poison resistance.

Eating the corpse or tin of Frankenstein's Monster grants one of cold resistance, shock resistance, sleep resistance, or poison resistance, with an equal 1⁄4 chance (25%) of each.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry
  • 5 References

Generation

Frankenstein's Monster is always created hostile, and will always generate with 400 HP.[1] He is not a valid form for polymorph.

Frankenstein's Monster is guaranteed to appear in Frankenstein's Lab, where he is found wandering the maze surrounding the lab at level creation.

Frankenstein's Monster leaves a corpse that is aged 100 turns upon death.[2]

Strategy

While Frankenstein's Monster has a lot of HP, solid AC of -5 and a sizable MR score of 50, he is slow at 8 speed and unlikely to be a threat for any hero that has reached Gehennom and found the laboratory's branch: his melee attacks hit only moderately hard for the depth he is encountered at, he lacks special abilities, and he is fairly slow at 8 speed. Most players can take advantage of his vulnerability to fire damage to make the fight much quicker.

As Frankenstein's Monster is mindless, locating him can be difficult - quaffing a blessed potion of monster detection or casting the detect monsters spell with Skilled or higher skill level in divination spells can make him easy to spot. For heroes who are determined to kill him, the corpse is generally unsuitable for consumption without using a tinning kit, but can provide valuable resistances should they lack any.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Frankenstein's monster

Frankenstein's monster (or Frankenstein's Creature) is the main antagonist of 1818 Mary Shelley novel Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus. The story itself begins with Captain Robert Walton on an exploration of the North Pole: Walton had come to the area in pursuit of scientific knowledge, and during the voyage his crew spotted a dog sled driven by a gigantic figure, later revealed to be Frankenstein's monster. A few hours later, they rescue a freezing and emaciated man from near-death, who identifies himself as Victor Frankenstein, the monster's creator; Victor then recounts his life story to Captain Walton as a warning.

While at university, Victor Frankenstein excels in chemistry and other sciences, developing a secret technique to give life to non-living matter. He undertakes the creation of a humanoid being over the course of two years in the attic of his boarding house in Ingolstadt. Due to the difficulty of replicating the minute parts of the human body, Victor makes his monster about 8 feet (2.4 m) in height and proportionally large, and selects for features commonly considered beautiful during the process.

Despite this, when the monster is finally animated he takes on a hideous appearance, with dull and watery yellow eyes and yellow skin that barely conceals the muscles and blood vessels underneath. Repulsed by his work, Victor flees from it in horror; frightened, and unaware of his own identity, the monster wanders through the wilderness. Far from being an unintelligent brute, the monster is an emotional, contemplative being that attempts to fit into human society, but his shunning leads him to seek revenge against Frankenstein.

Frankenstein's monster has since become iconic in popular culture, and has been featured in various forms of media, including films, television series, merchandise and video games; due to his significant role, the monster is commonly and erroneously referred to by "Frankenstein", his creator's name. The most popularly recognized versions are the trilogy of film portrayals by Boris Karloff: the 1931 film Frankenstein, the 1935 sequel Bride of Frankenstein, and the 1939 sequel Son of Frankenstein. Frankenstein's monster is described by scholar Joseph Carroll as occupying "a border territory between the characteristics that typically define protagonists and antagonists".

Encyclopedia entry

With an anxiety that almost amounted to agony, I collected
the instruments of life around me, that I might infuse a spark
of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet. It was
already one in the morning; the rain pattered dismally against
the panes, and my candle was nearly burnt out, when, by the
glimmer of the half-extinguished light, I saw the dull yellow
eye of the creature open; it breathed hard, and a convulsive
motion agitated its limbs.

How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, or how
delineate the wretch whom with such infinite pains and care I
had endeavoured to form? His limbs were in proportion, and I
had selected his features as beautiful. Beautiful!--Great God!
His yellow skin scarcely covered the work of muscles and
arteries beneath; his hair was of a lustrous black, and
flowing; his teeth of a pearly whiteness; but these luxuriances
only formed a more horrid contrast with his watery eyes, that
seemed almost of the same colour as the dun white sockets in
which they were set, his shrivelled complexion and straight
black lips.

[ Frankenstein, by Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley ]

References

  1. ↑ makemon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 2261
  2. ↑ mon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 258

'''Frankenstein's Monster''', {{monsym|Frankenstein's Monster}}, is a [[unique]] [[monster]] that appears in [[SLASH'EM]] and [[SlashTHEM]]. He is a [[strong]], [[undead]] [[golem]] that is very similar to a more powerful [[flesh golem]].

Frankenstein's Monster has two claw attacks and possesses [[cold resistance]], [[shock resistance]], [[sleep resistance]], and [[poison resistance]].

Eating the [[corpse]] or [[tin]] of Frankenstein's Monster grants one of cold resistance, shock resistance, sleep resistance, or poison resistance, with an equal {{frac|4}} chance (25%) of each.

==Generation==
Frankenstein's Monster is always created hostile, and will always generate with 400 [[HP]].{{refsrc|makemon.c|2261|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} He is not a valid form for [[polymorph]].

Frankenstein's Monster is guaranteed to appear in [[Frankenstein's Lab]], where he is found wandering the maze surrounding the lab at level creation.

Frankenstein's Monster leaves a corpse that is aged 100 turns upon death.{{refsrc|mon.c|258|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

==Strategy==
While Frankenstein's Monster has a lot of HP, solid [[AC]] of -5 and a sizable [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] of 50, he is slow at 8 [[speed]] and unlikely to be a threat for any [[hero]] that has reached [[Gehennom]] and found the laboratory's branch: his melee attacks hit only moderately hard for the depth he is encountered at, he lacks special abilities, and he is fairly slow at 8 [[speed]]. Most players can take advantage of his vulnerability to [[fire]] damage to make the fight much quicker.

As Frankenstein's Monster is [[mindless]], locating him can be difficult - [[quaffing]] a blessed [[potion of monster detection]] or casting the {{+ of|detect monsters}} spell with Skilled or higher [[skill]] level in [[divination spells]] can make him easy to spot. For heroes who are determined to kill him, the corpse is generally unsuitable for consumption without using a [[tinning kit]], but can provide valuable resistances should they lack any.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Frankenstein's monster}}
Frankenstein's monster (or Frankenstein's Creature) is the main antagonist of 1818 [[wikipedia:Mary Shelley|Mary Shelley]] novel ''[[wikipedia:Frankenstein|Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus]]''. The story itself begins with Captain Robert Walton on an exploration of the North Pole: Walton had come to the area in pursuit of scientific knowledge, and during the voyage his crew spotted a dog sled driven by a gigantic figure, later revealed to be Frankenstein's monster. A few hours later, they rescue a freezing and emaciated man from near-death, who identifies himself as [[Doctor Frankenstein|Victor Frankenstein]], the monster's creator; Victor then recounts his life story to Captain Walton as a warning.

While at university, Victor Frankenstein excels in chemistry and other sciences, developing a secret technique to give life to non-living matter. He undertakes the creation of a humanoid being over the course of two years in the attic of his boarding house in Ingolstadt. Due to the difficulty of replicating the minute parts of the human body, Victor makes his monster about 8 feet (2.4 m) in height and proportionally large, and selects for features commonly considered beautiful during the process.

Despite this, when the monster is finally animated he takes on a hideous appearance, with dull and watery yellow eyes and yellow skin that barely conceals the muscles and blood vessels underneath. Repulsed by his work, Victor flees from it in horror; frightened, and unaware of his own identity, the monster wanders through the wilderness. Far from being an unintelligent brute, the monster is an emotional, contemplative being that attempts to fit into human society, but his shunning leads him to seek revenge against Frankenstein. 

Frankenstein's monster has since become iconic in popular culture, and has been featured in various forms of media, including films, television series, merchandise and video games; due to his significant role, the monster is commonly and erroneously referred to by "Frankenstein", his creator's name. The most popularly recognized versions are the trilogy of film portrayals by [[wikipedia:Boris Karloff|Boris Karloff]]: the 1931 film ''[[wikipedia:Frankenstein (1931 film)|Frankenstein]]'', the 1935 sequel ''[[wikipedia:Bride of Frankenstein|Bride of Frankenstein]]'', and the 1939 sequel ''[[wikipedia:Son of Frankenstein|Son of Frankenstein]]''. Frankenstein's monster is described by scholar [[wikipedia:Joseph Carroll (scholar)|Joseph Carroll]] as occupying "a border territory between the characteristics that typically define protagonists and antagonists".
